question: 1 (m)
sols_html:
The strength of Newton’s method is on root finding. We’re asked to approximate

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}x=2^{1/6}\end{aligned}\]

which we can write as a root finding problem,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}x^6-2=0.\end{aligned}\]

With this in mind, let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}f(x) = x^6-2.\end{aligned}\]

Taking the derivative gives

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}f'(x) = 6x^5.\end{aligned}\]

We start with \(x_1=1\) as our first iteration and so if we apply Newton’s Method, we get,

\[\begin{aligned} x_{2} = x_{1} - \frac{f(x_{1})}{f'(x_{1})} = 1 - \frac{f(1)}{f'(1)} = 1 - \frac{-1}{6} = 1+\frac{1}{6} = \frac{7}{6}.\end{aligned}\]

If we actually compute \(2^{1/6}\) we get

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}2^{1/6}\approx{}1.122462048\end{aligned}\]

and so \(\frac{7}{6}=1.166666667\) is already in good agreement.
